section.title: Glossary of Terms
section.para: These terms are specific to the SolutionStudio environment, not to Linux or applications that run on Linux. They are arranged in alphabetical order.

listitem.para: The id for a solution. The default value consists of the /name, /version and /arch child elements of the main element in the solution definition in the format $NAME-$VERSION-$ARCH.
The server on which SolutionStudio is installed.
The target system on which solution contents are installed.

An RPM package created by SolutionStudio during the build process. This package contains the YUM sync plugin, SolutionStudio created YUM configuration, and user-specified configuration files and scripts. The name of the configuration package is in the following format, where $VERSION is taken from the version element in the solution definition and $RELEASE is taken from the .
For example, given a solution with the name "samba-server" and version "5", the first time SolutionStudio creates the solution, the configuration package will be named as follows:

The release number "1" will be written to the solution data file. When configuration changes in the future, e.g. when files or scripts are added, deleted or modified, SolutionStudio will increment the release number by 1, create a new configuration package (in this case samba-server-config-5-2.noarch.rpm), and store the new release number ("2") in the solution data file. The incremented version number allows installed client machines to determine that a new configuration package is available for download and installation.
For more information on what the configuration package contains and how to customize its contents, see the section on config in the Solution Definition File Reference.
"Solution Definition File Reference," the rules of syntax for the solution definition.
The information SolutionStudio uses to build, configure and store a solution. By convention the text file uses the .definition extension. The file uses XML tagging as defined in the SDFR.

A file SolutionStudio creates to track and increment the release number of the solution's . This file is created in the same folder as the solution definition, using the same filename, with a .dat file extension. For example, given the full path to a solution definition:

Care should be taken not to delete this file. Doing so will cause the release number of the configuration package to restart at "1". As a result, updated configuration packages will fail to be downloaded and installed during client machine updates.

The web location (URL) for downloading solution content. SolutionStudio uses this location during the build process for two purposes, for creating YUM client configuration (included in the ), and for customizing network install images. By default the download location is as follows, where $IP_ADDRESS is the address of the build machine, and $ID is the solution id.
For example, if the IP Address for the build machine is 192.168.1.5 and the solution id is samba-server-5-i386 the download location is as follows:

The download location is configurable using the publish element of the solution definition. See the SDFR for information on the publish element. See also for a discussion on using download locations in a production environment.

RPM package repository created during the solution build process. Provides packages for use during client machine installations and updates. Can be accessed over the network from the os folder of the .
Within a SolutionStudio development - staging - production environment, it serves as the download server from which clients retrieve the solution contents to install.
The server within a development - staging - production environment that uses SolutionStudio to build production-ready solutions for migration to the production, or download, server.

A YUM plugin provided by SolutionStudio that allows synchronizing packages on client machines with packages in the . The plugin is included by default in the , which serves as the mechanism for installing it on client machines. The plugin establishes the solution repository as the master repository, disables all non-master repositories, and provides a new argument, sync, to YUM. Help for the sync argument is available on client machines using the yum help command. Running yum sync allows YUM to calculate package additions and removals based on packages available in the solution repository. For more information, see the section on .
